周四，前议员玛丽亚·科里纳·马查多被正式宣布为委内瑞拉反对派周末总统初选的胜利者，一名政府官员警告外国外交官不要干涉选举进程。

该国总检察长周三表示，他的办公室已对初选及其组织委员会成员展开刑事调查。

这项调查可能会激怒美国，美国上周放松了对尼古拉斯·马杜罗总统政府的一些制裁，因为美国政府在与巴巴多斯反对派达成的协议中承诺明年举行公平选举。

美国国务院已经表示，如果马杜罗政府不取消对马查多等人的公职禁令，并在11月底前释放政治犯和“错误拘留”的美国人，美国国务院将恢复之前的制裁。

2019 年，马杜罗赢得连任后，制裁范围广泛扩大，美国和其他国家称这是一次欺诈性投票。

马查多在初选中赢得约 93% 的选票，周三在党总部会见了约 10 名外国外交官，引发了政府的反对。

“恕我直言……不要干涉内部问题，”执政党立法机构主席豪尔赫·罗德里格斯(Jorge Rodriguez)周四在与一大群外交官会面时对他们说，记者在一旁观看。

政府没有提供会议与会者名单。

与反对派谈判的政府首席谈判代表罗德里格斯告诉外交官，初选违反了选举规则，因为初选是在没有选举当局帮助的情况下组织的，并且违反了巴巴多斯协议。

然而，马查多表示，对初选的调查“明显”违反了巴巴多斯协议。

“我们希望事情不会继续下去，”她在宣布初选最终计票结果的新闻发布会上说。

接受调查的委员会主席赫苏斯·玛丽亚·卡萨尔 (Jesus Maria Casal) 表示，初选组织委员会试图让选举当局参与，但没有成功。

他没有对调查发表评论。

从支持乌克兰到增强军事实力和管理移民，欧盟领导人周四在开始讨论未来四年从共同预算中投入更多资金的问题时，提出了不同的优先事项。

欧盟将于 12 月决定修改其价值 1.1 万亿欧元（1.2 万亿美元）的 2021-27 年预算，该预算已因新冠疫情大流行期间和俄罗斯 2022 年入侵乌克兰以来的紧急支出而紧张。

欧盟执行委员会建议成员国向共同金库投入更多资金， 向乌克兰提供500亿欧元，并另外在移民方面支出150亿欧元。另一项提议是向乌克兰拨款200亿美元的军事援助。

预算决定需要一致同意，周四，欧盟 27 国领导人抵达布鲁塞尔参加峰会时，分歧就显现出来了。

比利时首相亚历山大·德克罗表示：“今天摆在桌面上的事情对我们来说是不可接受的。”

他支持欧盟继续支持乌克兰，但呼吁采取不同的方式为新支出提供资金。

“我们要求委员会和其他机构审视自己的资金，审视未充分利用的资金……而不是要求成员国提供更多捐款。”

在欧盟东翼，爱沙尼亚总理卡亚·卡拉斯表示，除了支持乌克兰之外，还应该增加联合支出，以提高欧盟的防御能力。立陶宛表示，为乌克兰提供500亿欧元还不够。

斯洛伐克的罗伯特·菲科在第四次被任命为总理一天后抵达峰会，他表示他不会同意向乌克兰提供更多军事援助。

“我们只会专注于人道主义援助，”他在布鲁塞尔的社交媒体上写道。

在南部，希腊请求为移民提供更多资金，因为该集团正在努力收紧外部边界并减少来自中东和非洲的未经授权的入境者。

希腊总理基里亚科斯·米佐塔基斯表示：“希腊是最先接待的国家，需要欧洲提供更多支持来解决移民问题。”

“尚未匹配”

这一说法很快遭到欧盟最坚定的反移民声音之一匈牙利总理欧尔班·维克托的拒绝，他表示布达佩斯反对向“移民、一体化政策和乌克兰人”提供资金。

欧尔班表示，匈牙利不会支持对乌克兰提供更多援助，除非它看到“非常合理的提议”。

“我们面前的那个……这是行不通的。所以，暂时我们也会拒绝这一点，我们将在 12 月份看看会取得什么结果。”

欧尔班发表此番言论之际，其政府正试图释放欧盟预算中为匈牙利设想的数十亿美元援助，但因法治问题而被欧盟委员会阻止。

爱尔兰的利奥·瓦拉德卡 (Leo Varadkar) 在一长串相互冲突的优先事项中添加了对欧盟竞争力的投资。

他说：“当然，这笔钱是在哪里找到的，这将是一个有争议的问题。”

外交官们表示，去年夏天遭受自然灾害的国家正在寻求帮助，而奥地利则带头呼吁在西巴尔干国家增加支出。

欧盟金主德国领导人奥拉夫·肖尔茨(Olaf Scholz)总结称，谈判才刚刚真正开始：“我们仍处于起步阶段，立场……尚未匹配。”

阿拉伯世界对以色列无情轰炸被围困的巴勒斯坦领土日益愤怒，以色列地面部队连夜对加沙地带的哈马斯目标进行了大规模袭击。

以色列总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡曾表示，以色列军队仍在为全面地面入侵做准备，而美国和其他国家则敦促以色列推迟此类行动，担心这可能会引发中东其他战线的敌对行动。

向加沙巴勒斯坦平民提供援助的联合国机构表示，如果没有燃料到达哈马斯统治的领土，因为迫切需要住所、水、食物和医疗服务，该机构可能不得不很快停止行动。

10 月 7 日哈马斯袭击以色列社区后，以色列对人口稠密的加沙地带进行了近三周的轰炸。以色列称哈马斯杀害了约 1,400 人，并劫持了 200 多人作为人质。

加沙卫生部周四表示，7,028名巴勒斯坦人在报复性空袭中丧生，其中包括2,913名儿童。

周三，美国总统乔·拜登对巴勒斯坦伤亡数字表示怀疑，以色列军方发言人称该数字不可信。

军方尚未对自己进行任何评估，加沙卫生部发言人阿什拉夫·齐德拉拒绝了质疑这些数字的声明。

该部周四发布了一份文件，称其中包含所有已识别受害者的姓名及其身份证号码。

以色列陆军电台称，军方一夜之间对加沙北部发动了本次战争中最大规模的入侵。一段军事视频显示，装甲车越过戒备森严的边境并炸毁了建筑物。

报告称：“坦克和步兵袭击了许多恐怖组织、基础设施和反坦克导弹发射站。”

巴勒斯坦人表示，以色列隔夜再次空袭该领土，加沙中部地区的民众报告整夜遭到坦克密集炮击。

阿拉伯的批评

加沙局势没有任何缓和的迹象，巴林、埃及、约旦、科威特、摩洛哥、阿曼、卡塔尔、沙特阿拉伯和阿拉伯联合酋长国的外交部长谴责了他们所谓的针对平民和违反国际法的行为。

他们的联合声明称，以色列的自卫权并不能成为违法和忽视巴勒斯坦人权利的理由。阿拉伯部长们谴责对加沙巴勒斯坦人的强迫流离失所和集体惩罚。

他们还批评以色列对巴勒斯坦地区的占领，并呼吁加大力度实施两国解决方案来解决长达数十年的冲突——这是长期停滞的和平建设的核心理念。

报告称：“巴以冲突缺乏政治解决方案，导致暴力行为一再发生，巴勒斯坦和以色列人民以及该地区人民遭受苦难。”

对以色列的支持来自欧洲各国政府。

德国总理奥拉夫·肖尔茨表示，周五在布鲁塞尔举行的欧盟领导人会议将发出支持以色列的明确信号。

肖尔茨说：“我们可以肯定，以色列军队所做的一切都会尊重国际法的规则。”

但比利时首相亚历山大·德克罗的言辞反映了欧盟内部的分歧，警告以色列不要让加沙挨饿。

他说，以色列有权采取行动并防止未来的袭击。

“但这绝不是封锁整个地区、阻止人道主义援助的借口。这不能成为让人民挨饿的借口。”

人质

人们对 10 月 7 日袭击中哈马斯劫持并被带到加沙的 200 多名人质的命运也日益担忧。

哈马斯武装组织卡萨姆旅的发言人周四表示，由于以色列的袭击，加沙已有约 50 名俘虏被杀。他没有提供更多细节，路透社也无法核实这些数字。

以色列称，有 224 名人质，他们的存在使以色列的地面入侵变得更加复杂。这包括许多外国护照持有者。自周五以来，哈马斯已经释放了四名俘虏。

一名卡塔尔谈判代表告诉天空新闻，暂停战斗可能有助于在未来几天释放更多人质。

卡塔尔外交大臣穆罕默德·胡莱菲表示：“这是一场非常非常困难的谈判……随着轰炸每天都在持续，我们的任务变得更加困难。但尽管如此，我们仍然充满希望。”

更多死亡

在加沙北部的贾巴利亚难民营，以色列空袭击中了一座房屋，造成一名母亲、她的三个女儿和一名男婴死亡，男婴的父亲将尸体送往医院。

“他杀了人吗？他打伤了人吗？他抓了人吗？他们是家里无辜的孩子，”他说。

据哈马斯阿克萨广播电台报道，南部城市汗尤尼斯的纳赛尔医院院长纳赫德·阿布·塔埃马表示，77名在空袭中丧生的人的尸体已在一夜之间运抵，其中大多数是妇女和儿童。

纳赛尔医院官员表示，周四中午左右，以色列轰炸了近东救济工程处流离失所者避难所附近的一个地区，造成至少 18 人死亡。

以色列表示，其部队袭击了汗尤尼斯地区哈马斯的一个导弹发射站，该发射站毗邻一座清真寺和幼儿园。目前尚不清楚双方是否指的是同一事件。

在以色列警告他们离开北部家园后，许多巴勒斯坦人在汗尤尼斯医院、学校、家庭和难民营以及街头避难。

联合国巴勒斯坦难民机构近东救济工程处表示，迫切需要燃料来维持加沙的救生人道主义行动。以色列拒绝将燃料与援助物资一起运入，称其可能被哈马斯扣押。

超过 613,000 名因战争而无家可归的人在这片破碎地区的 150 个近东救济工程处设施中避难。

人道主义供应严重不足，但世界大国未能在联合国就如何呼吁平息战斗以提供大量援助达成一致。

伊朗外长侯赛因·阿米拉卜杜拉希安在联合国发言时表示，如果以色列不停止对哈马斯的进攻，美国将“无法幸免于这场大火”。

以色列联合国特使周四向拥有 193 名成员国的联合国大会展示了一段简短的视频，他说视频中一名哈马斯战士在巴勒斯坦武装分子 10 月 7 日袭击以色列期间试图用园艺工具将一名男子斩首。

吉拉德·埃尔丹大使告诉外交官，他在平板电脑上为他们播放的几秒钟视频中看到的受害者不是以色列人或犹太人，而是一名来自泰国的农业工人。

埃尔丹对集会说：“人们可以看到一名受重伤的平民——血迹斑斑，但还活着——躺在地上，一名哈马斯野蛮人尖叫着阿拉胡·阿克巴（Allahu Akbar）反复用锄头敲击该男子的脖子，以将他斩首。”

埃尔丹的评论是在大会周四开始为期两天的中东问题会议时发表的。

阿拉伯国家起草的一项决议将于周五进行投票，该决议呼吁以色列和哈马斯在加沙地带的战争停火。

在联合国总部大厅的每个座位上，以色列外交官都放置了一张二维码，上面写着“从哈马斯手中解放加沙，扫描看看哈马斯的暴行”。它链接到 10 月 7 日袭击事件的照片和视频。

以色列誓言要消灭统治加沙的哈马斯，以报复造成 1,400 人死亡的袭击。以色列从空中袭击了加沙，围困了这片拥有 230 万人口的飞地，并准备进行地面入侵。巴勒斯坦当局称已有 7,000 多人被杀。

约旦外交部长艾曼·萨法迪代表阿拉伯国家发言，指责以色列“使加沙成为永久的人间地狱——这种创伤将困扰子孙后代”。他说，这对巴勒斯坦平民的影响是巨大的。

“我没有视频可以给你们看，我们太尊重死者了，”萨法迪说。

巴勒斯坦联合国特使里亚德·曼苏尔主张停火，他表示，某些国家（他没有透露具体名称）正在采用明显的双重标准。

“各国代表如何解释 1,000 名以色列人被杀是多么可怕，而当现在每天都有 1,000 名巴勒斯坦人被杀时，他们又如何不感到同样的愤怒呢？”曼苏尔向大会询问。 “为什么不感到结束杀戮的紧迫感呢？”

前一天晚上，刘易斯顿市一家保龄球馆和一家酒吧发生枪击事件，造成 18 人死亡、13 人受伤，缅因州警方周四正在通缉一名因谋杀罪通缉的美国陆军预备役军人。

在不断扩大的搜捕行动中，警方在缅因州南部呈扇形展开，对罗伯特·R·卡德（Robert R. Card）发出了逮捕令。罗伯特·卡德是附近美国陆军预备役基地的一名中士，执法官员称他今年夏天被暂时关押在一家精神卫生机构。

警方散发的照片显示，一名留着胡须的男子穿着棕色连帽运动衫和牛仔裤，在一个犯罪现场，手持一把似乎是半自动步枪的武器。

该地区的公立学区周四取消了课程，警方敦促居民留在室内。

美国总统乔·拜登呼应其他官员的说法，在一份声明中表示，他对在这个致命枪支暴力司空见惯的国家发生的“又一起毫无意义和悲剧性的大规模枪击事件”表示哀悼。他再次敦促国会通过禁止大容量弹匣和其他枪支法规。

“这对缅因州来说是黑暗的一天，”民主党州长珍妮特·米尔斯在新闻发布会上说。 “卡德先生被认为携带武器且危险，警方建议缅因州民众在任何情况下都不应接近他。”

缅因州警方发现了一辆白色SUV，他们认为卡德将其开往刘易斯顿东南约7英里（11公里）处的里斯本镇，并敦促刘易斯顿和里斯本的人们留在室内。警方还要求卡德的家乡鲍登 (Bowdoin) 的居民就地避难，鲍登位于刘易斯顿 (Lewiston) 以东约 12 英里处。

Even though Israel has invested heavily in tunnel detection - including a sensor-equipped underground barrier it called an "iron wall" - Hamas is still thought to have working tunnels to the outside world.

After the last round of hostilities in 2021, Hamas's leader in Gaza, Yehya Al-Sinwar, said: "They started saying they destroyed 100kms of Hamas tunnels. I am telling you, the tunnels we have in the Gaza Strip exceed 500kms. Even if their narrative is true, they only destroyed 20% of the tunnels."

HOSTAGE WITNESS

There has been no corroboration of the comment by Sinwar, who is thought to be hiding underground ahead of an expected Israeli ground offensive.

But the estimate of hundreds of kilometres is widely accepted by security analysts, even though the blockaded coastal strip is only 40km (25 miles) long.

With Israel in full control of Gaza's air and sea access and 59km of its 72km land borders - with Egypt 13km to the south - tunnels provide one of the few ways for Hamas to bring in weapons, equipment and people.

While it and other Palestinian groups are secretive about their networks, recently released Israeli hostage, 85-year-old Yocheved Lifshitz , said: "It looked like a spider's web, many, many tunnels," adding: "We walked kilometres under the ground."

Hamas believes that with Israel's overwhelming aerial and armoured military superiority, tunnels are a way to cut some of those advantages by forcing Israel's soldiers to move underground in cramped spaces the Hamas fighters know well.

An Israeli military spokesperson said on Thursday: "I won't elaborate on the number of kilometres of tunnels but it is a high number, built under schools and residential areas."

Urging the United Nations Security Council to intervene, Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas has called for an immediate cessation of "aggression" on Gaza and moves toward "a political solution instead of military and security solutions".

UNDERGROUND CITY

Israeli security sources say Israel's heavy aerial bombardments have caused little damage to the tunnel infrastructure with Hamas naval commandos able to launch a seaborne attack targeting coastal communities near Gaza this week.

"Although we have been attacking massively for days and days, the (Hamas) leadership is pretty much intact, as is the ability to command and control, the ability even to try and launch counter attacks," said Amir Avivi, a former brigadier general whose senior positions in the Israeli military included deputy commander of the Gaza division, tasked with tackling tunnels.

"There is a whole city all over Gaza underneath with depths of 40-50 metres. There are bunkers and headquarters and storage and of course they are connected to more than a thousand rocket launching positions."

Other sources estimated depths of up to 80 metres.

One Western security source said: "They run for miles. They are made of concrete and very well made. Think of the Viet Cong times 10. They have had years and lots of money with which to work with."

Another security source, from one of Israel's neighbouring countries, said Hamas's tunnels from Egypt remain active.

"The supply chain is still intact these days. The network involved in facilitating co-ordination are some Egyptian military officers. It is unclear if there is knowledge of this by the Egyptian army," he said.

A small number of narrower, deep, smuggling tunnels were still operating until recently between Egypt and Gaza, according to two security sources and a trader in the Egyptian city of El Arish, but they had slowed to a near-halt since the Israel-Hamas war started.

Egyptian officials did not immediately respond to a request for comment. On Wednesday, Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi said while inspecting military units in Suez that the army's role was to secure Egyptian borders.

LONG GAME

Hamas was created in Gaza in 1987 and is thought to have begun digging tunnels in the mid-1990s, when Israel granted Yasser Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization some degree of self-rule in Gaza.

The tunnel network is a key reason why Hamas is stronger in Gaza than in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, where Israel's settlements, military bases and monitoring devices make it harder to get anything in from Jordan.

Tunneling became easier in 2005 when Israel pulled its soldiers and settlers out of Gaza, and when Hamas won power in a 2006 election.

Shortly afterwards Hamas's military wing, the Izz el-Deen al-Qassam Brigades, captured Gilad Shalit and killed two other Israeli soldiers after burrowing 600 metres to raid the Kerem Shalom base on the Gaza border.

A year later Hamas launched a military strike against Arafat's forces in Gaza using tunnel-mounted attacks.

Although the military tunnels remained off-limits to outside eyes, during that era Gaza smugglers would show off their scarcely concealed commercial tunnels under the Rafah border.

These were around three feet (one metre) wide and used winch motors to haul goods along the sandy tunnel floors in hollowed-out petrol barrels.

One Rafah tunnel operator, Abu Qusay, said a half-mile tunnel took three to six months to dig and could yield profits of up to $100,000 a day. The most profitable item was bullets, bought for $1 each in Egypt and fetching more than $6 in Gaza. Kalashnikov rifles, he said, cost $800 in Egypt and sold for twice that.

In 2007 the military wing is thought to have brought its commander Mohammed Deif into Gaza through a tunnel from Egypt. Deif was the mastermind behind Hamas's deadly Oct. 7 attack into Israel, which killed 1,400 people and hostages were taken.

TUNNEL HUNTING

Professor Joel Roskin, a geomorphologist and geologist with Israel's Bar-Ilan University said it was difficult to map the tunnel network accurately from the surface or space, adding highly classified information was essential for 3D mapping and imagery visualization.

Among the elite units tasked with going underground is Yahalom, specialist commandos from Israel's Combat Engineering Corps known as the "weasels", who specialise in finding, clearing and destroying the tunnels.

Earlier this week Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu visited Yahalom fighters, telling them: "I rely on you, the people of Israel rely on you."

Israeli sources said what awaits them is formidable and they faced an enemy that has regrouped and learned from previous Israeli operations in 2014 and 2021.

"There are going to be a lot of booby traps. They have thermobaric weapons that they didn't have in 2021, which are more lethal. And I believe they acquired a lot of anti-tank weapon systems that are going to try to hit our APCs (armoured personnel carriers), tanks," said Amnon Sofrin, a former brigadier general and former commander of the Combat Intelligence Corps.

Sofrin, who was also previously head of the intelligence directorate with Israel's Mossad spy agency, said Hamas would also be trying to kidnap soldiers.

Daphne Richemond-Barak, professor at Israel's Reichman University and author of the book Underground Warfare, said the conflicts in Syria and Iraq had changed the situation.

"What the IDF (Israeli military) is likely to face inside the tunnels is also all of the experience and all of the knowledge that has been gained by groups like ISIS (Islamic State) and has been ... passed on to Hamas."

Brazilian lawmakers have set up a congressional caucus to represent Brazil's oil and gas industry, led by state-run producer Petrobras (PETR4.SA) , and to back the company's plans to explore offshore fields near the mouth of the Amazon River.

"Petrobras has to do that. We have to explore for oil off-shore from Para to Amapa states, like Guyana and Venezuela are doing," the leader of the caucus, retired army general Eduardo Pazuello, said in an interview late on Wednesday.

Petrobras has planned to explore in the so-called Northern Brazilian Equatorial Margin, following major discoveries in neighboring Guyana and Suriname. But Brazil's environmental protection agency has denied the company a license and asked for more studies on the risks of drilling there.

President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva's cabinet is divided over drilling in the region. The Mines and Energy Ministry favors drilling, but environmental officials have blocked it.

"The government is split, but it will do it. We have to explore for oil at the mouth of the Amazon," Pazuello said.

Environmental groups have called on the government to block exploration near the mouth of the Amazon, arguing that it will damage a vulnerable and little-studied area where South America's biggest river flows into the Atlantic ocean.

Neighboring states want exploration to proceed because it will bring investment and jobs.

The Parliamentary Front in Support of Oil, Gas and Energy, as the caucus is called, was launched on Tuesday with 217 members, or 42% of the lower chamber of Congress.

Pazuello said the caucus will work in the interests of energy producers and distributors, along with hundreds of oil and gas equipment and service providers, including foreign firms such as Norway's Equinor (EQNR.OL) , the second-biggest operator in Brazil after Petrobras.

He said the launch of the caucus received unprecedented support in Congress and was a non-partisan effort. Its deputy leader is Washington Quaquá, of President Lula's Workers Party.

The caucus will seek to mobilize political support in Congress to press the government to explore near the mouth of the Amazon and pass legislation to expand energy infrastructure in Brazil.

Pazuello said Brazil is a world leader in renewable energy sources, with 85% of its electricity provided by hydroelectric, wind, solar or nuclear generators, but the transition to cleaner energy will continue to require oil and even coal for some time.

Pazuello, who was health minister for former far-right President Jair Bolsonaro during the pandemic, was elected to Congress in 2022 from Rio de Janeiro, the state where much of Brazil's oil industry is based.

After Hamas' shock attack on Israel, Shimrit Ben Arosh, a mother from an Israeli settlement in the occupied West Bank, drove up to a shooting range in central Kfar Saba for gun license firearms training.

"I have six children, and after the incident of the 7th of October, I understood that I must protect myself. The nights are very frightening, and so I wanted to get a license for a gun, to be safe, to protect my children," she said.

Aghast at the Hamas killing spree in their southern towns and villages, and worried by the military's slow response, Israelis are arming themselves in record numbers with the blessing of their government.

Gun stores and shooting ranges have been working overtime to accommodate the sudden demand, with some former advocates of stricter firearms controls among the new clients.

Israel has been bombarding the Gaza Strip since Hamas's attack on Israeli communities on Oct. 7, which it says killed some 1,400 people.

On Thursday it said its ground forces had made a big push into Gaza overnight to attack Hamas targets as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said it was still preparing for a ground invasion that could be one of several.

According to Channel 13 TV, there have been 150,000 applications for gun licenses since the cross-border onslaught - compared to just 42 applications in the same period last year.

Firearms sales are highly restricted in Israel, and obtaining a civilian firearms license is no easy feat. An application can sometimes take months.

Some survivors of the rampage credit the guns they had near to hand, with which they said they defended their homes until security forces arrived - often after delays of several hours.

The far-right minister for police, Itamar Ben-Gvir, has also described private gun ownership as a precaution against any recurrence of the internal unrest between Israel's Arab minority and Jewish majority that accompanied the last Gaza war, in 2021.

Netanyahu has said Israel was in an all-out war against Hamas. This included "encouraging civilians and helping civilians to arm themselves for their self-defence," he said in a televised speech on Wednesday.

The gun licenses - usually for pistols, rather than rifles - once took months to process. They can now be obtained in just days online. Before, it was mostly veterans of military combat units or residents of frontline towns who qualified. Now a year of civilian national service can suffice, the police ministry says.

Arab citizens of Israel, many of whom identify as Palestinian, are generally exempted from mandatory conscription and may not be able to get a license.

Gil Shemesh, a firearms instructor at the shooting range, said the swelling number of applicants has been overwhelming and includes "people living in dangerous areas, to normal people who just want to protect themselves because they saw what happened."

The company is hiring new instructors just to keep up, he said.

With state coffers empty, many also wonder who would pay to rebuild. Some question whether Sunni-led Gulf Arab states that financed reconstruction in 2006 would rush to help this time, given Hezbollah's bigger role in Lebanon.

One senior Lebanese official said governments had contacted Lebanon to cool tensions.

"We're telling them that instead of telling us to restrain Hezbollah, they need to put pressure on the Israelis not to escalate," he said.

The last several years have been particularly difficult for Lebanon, which has known little stability since independence and endured wars including Israeli invasions in 1978 and 1982.

Decades of corruption and mismanagement by ruling politicians led the financial system to collapse in 2019, wiping out savings, demolishing the currency and fuelling poverty.

Karabakh, regarded internationally as part of Azerbaijan, had been ruled by breakaway ethnic Armenians since the breakup of the Soviet Union in the 1990s until last month.

Pashinyan also said on Thursday that Armenia hopes to open its border with Turkey, a close ally of Azerbaijan, to citizens of third countries and holders of diplomatic passports.

That frontier has been closed since 1993, when Turkey cut off relations with Armenia as war raged between Yerevan and Baku over Nagorno-Karabakh. Turkey has declined to reopen the border without a peace settlement between Yerevan and Baku.

Separately, the Kremlin said on Thursday it hoped that Armenian authorities would clarify comments made by Pashinyan in an interview with the Wall Street Journal that he saw no advantage in retaining Russian military bases in Armenia.

According to a full transcript of the interview published by Armenian state news agency Armenpress on Thursday, Pashinyan also said that Yerevan was "not discussing" calling on Russia to remove its troops from Armenia.

Russia has several military facilities in Christian Armenia, which remains a treaty ally of Moscow. Relations have soured in recent months, with Armenia accusing Moscow of failing to support it against mainly Muslim Azerbaijan, with which Russia is also allied.

In its turn, Moscow has accused Pashinyan of neglecting Armenia's traditional close ties with Russia and pivoting increasingly towards the West.

夏威夷以西 2000 英里处的太平洋环礁似乎将掀起建设热潮，美国和澳大利亚周四承诺为偏远的坎顿岛提供一个码头，而中国正在考虑恢复二战时期机场的计划。

基里巴斯有 115,000 名人口，分布在 33 个环礁，海洋面积超过 350 万平方公里（130 万平方英里），在不同时期一直是美国和中国太空跟踪站的基地。

尤其是一个环礁，在中国于 2019 年与基里巴斯恢复外交关系（发音为“kiribass”）后，最近成为华盛顿和北京关注的焦点。

关东岛是一片狭长的陆地，有些地方只有50米宽，但长达43公里的长岛内有一个平行四边形的泻湖。第二次世界大战期间，这里是美国的军事基地，拥有足以容纳大型船只的码头，也是美国和澳大利亚之间航班的加油站。

基里巴斯表示希望在那里建造一家酒店以吸引游客。

美国总统乔·拜登和澳大利亚总理安东尼·阿尔巴内斯在周四的联合声明中表示，他们将共同资助基里巴斯的海上基础设施，并重建坎顿码头。

美国在上个月举行的太平洋岛屿白宫峰会上已承诺提供 2900 万美元帮助基里巴斯青年就业。

中国方面于3月份派出专家前往该环礁进行建设坎顿岛机场的可行性研究，从本月起中国游客可以免签前往基里巴斯。

一名中国驻基里巴斯外交官周四在一份声明中告诉路透社，该提案仍在研究中。

然而，《中国日报》上个月的一篇社论称，美国试图阻止中国的计划。

这位中国外交官表示，基里巴斯已退出本月在北京举行的中国“一带一路”论坛，理由是该国需要准备主办太平洋岛屿渔业会议。基里巴斯政府没有回应置评请求。

澳大利亚国立大学太平洋问题专家格雷姆·史密斯表示，在太平洋岛国的战略竞争中，基里巴斯被视为“一个值得争夺的国家——无论它属于中国阵营还是美国阵营”。

“这里是西太平洋，确实是美国的后院。它离夏威夷非常近，”他说。

根据 20 世纪 80 年代签订的自由联合协定（COFA），美国保留了对这些国家的防务责任，华盛顿承诺向附近的帕劳、密克罗尼西亚联邦和马绍尔群岛提供数十亿美元的经济支持。

史密斯说，基里巴斯在地理位置上同样重要，但没有达成这样的协议。
